skill.name: style-audit
skill.description: Audits code against CI/CD style rules, quality guidelines, and best practices, then rewrites code to meet standards without breaking functionality. Use this skill after functionality validation to ensure code is not just correct but also maintainable, readable, and production-ready. The skill applies linting rules, enforces naming conventions, improves code organization, and refactors for clarity while preserving all behavioral correctness verified by functionality audits.
skill.summary: Audits code against CI/CD style rules, quality guidelines, and best practices, then rewrites code to...
skill.author: DNYoussef

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown and Graphviz diagram files. No executable code, no network calls, no filesystem access beyond reading its own files, and no code execution capabilities. This skill is a prompt-based documentation artifact with zero security risk.

content.value_statement: Code that works is not enough. Poor style creates confusion, accumulates technical debt, and slows team collaboration. This skill transforms functionally correct code into maintainable, production-grade code by applying systematic style audits and refactoring.
actual_capabilities: Runs automated linting tools appropriate to each programming language
Performs manual style review for decomposition, naming, organization, and complexity
Identifies security vulnerabilities and performance issues in code
Rewrites code to improve clarity while preserving functionality
Enhances documentation including docstrings, comments, and API docs
Produces comprehensive quality reports with metrics and findings
limitations: Requires functionality-audit to pass first (validates code works)
Does not add new features or change functionality scope
Cannot run actual linting tools directly (guides execution)
Depends on user-provided linting configurations and team standards

use_cases.title: Pre-commit code preparation
use_cases.description: Audit code before committing to catch style issues early and ensure consistency with team standards

use_cases.title: Systematic code review
use_cases.description: Apply consistent style criteria across pull requests using automated and manual review methodology

use_cases.title: Codebase quality standards
use_cases.description: Enforce team-wide code quality through systematic auditing and refactoring workflows

prompt_templates.title: Basic style audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a style audit on the files in my project. Identify formatting issues, naming convention violations, and basic style problems.

prompt_templates.title: Comprehensive audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform a complete style audit on my codebase including automated linting analysis, manual style review, security review, and documentation assessment. Report all findings categorized by severity.

prompt_templates.title: Refactoring with tests
prompt_templates.prompt: Audit and refactor my code to improve style. Apply automated fixes first, then manually refactor for clarity. Verify all functionality is preserved by running tests after each significant change.

prompt_templates.title: Team standards enforcement
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply my team's style guidelines to the codebase. Use our linting configuration files. Generate a detailed report showing before and after metrics with remaining issues prioritized by impact.

output_examples.input: Audit my JavaScript code and improve the style
output: Found 23 style issues: 8 formatting, 6 naming, 4 complexity, 3 documentation, 2 error handling
Fixed 8 formatting issues automatically with Prettier
Renamed 6 variables for clarity (e.g., 'd' â†’ 'userData', 'processItem' â†’ 'validateAndProcessItem')
Extracted 2 complex functions into smaller, single-purpose helpers

best_practices: Run style-audit after functionality-audit confirms code works correctly
Provide team linting configurations to ensure alignment with existing standards
Commit style improvements in small, atomic commits to ease review and reversion
anti_patterns: Running style-audit before functionality-audit (may refactor broken code)
Applying style fixes without running tests to verify functionality
Ignoring automated linting output in favor of subjective preferences

faq.question: What programming languages does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill methodology works with any language. It references Python tools like pylint and flake8, JavaScript tools like ESLint and Prettier, and adapts to other languages with their standard linters.

faq.question: How long does a style audit take?
faq.answer: Time varies by codebase size and current quality. Small files may take minutes. Large or poor-quality codebases may require multiple sessions to address all issues systematically.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my code directly?
faq.answer: The skill can apply automated fixes like formatting. For manual refactoring, it presents changes for review before applying them. You control the level of automation.

faq.question: Is my code data sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No. This skill operates entirely within your development environment. Code is processed locally and never transmitted to external services.

faq.question: What if tests fail after style changes?
faq.answer: The skill verifies functionality after each significant change. If tests fail, it identifies the breaking change immediately and helps you decide whether to revert or adjust the refactoring.

faq.question: How does this differ from functionality-audit?
faq.answer: functionality-audit verifies code works correctly (no mocks, genuine implementation). style-audit improves how code is written (readability, maintainability, standards). Run functionality-audit first, then style-audit.
